subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit Testing Code That Has System.exit(n);
msgSnippet: ... This is pretty much what I also suggested earlier. something like this should work for it too (in your test code): Process p = Runtime.exec( java mystuff )
messageBody:
2006/9/10, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...>:
>
> Back to the original problem, the only way I can think of is to sit down
> and
> think about what the return code really means: it sets a variable on the
> shell.
>
> So maybe you would fork a JVM that runs the code under test and then
> inspect
> the environment of the shell that was created and check the return value.
>
>
This is pretty much what I also suggested earlier.
something like this should work for it too (in your test code):

Process p = Runtime.exec("java mystuff")

int exitcode = p.waitFor();
assertmystuff(exitcode,...);
